channel.title: cata-list
channel.description: Useful lists of some of the best info, media, tools, and quotes for those who seek to understand and improve this world.

item.title: For Five Months, BLM Protestors Trashed America's Cities. After the Election, Things May Only Get Worse
item.description: This week marks the first time in living memory that widespread violence was widely viewed as a foreseeable, and even expected, outcome of an American national election. The votes are being counted just days after riots broke out in Philadelphia, causing the governor to deploy the National Guard in …

item.title: U.S. Exits Paris Climate Accord After Trump Stalls Global Warming Action for Four Years
item.description: State-level efforts and a growing renewables market have mitigated federal emissions policy rollbacks—but Trump’s climate impact could be long-lasting

item.title: Deep Neural Networks Are Helping Decipher How Brains Work
item.description: Neuroscientists are finding that deep-learning networks, often criticized as 'black boxes,' can be good models for the organization of living brains.

item.title: Oregon Just Voted to Decriminalize All Drugs
item.description: Oregon voters have taken a big step toward ending the war on drugs.

item.title: The Failing Business Model of American Universities
item.description: Put yourself in the shoes of the average college graduate today. It took you longer than expected to complete your 'four-year degree' and you are almost $30,000 in debt. You are desperately searching for a job in your field before your student loan payments run you into the ground, assuming your ren…

item.title: Raspberry Pi 400: The $70 Desktop PC
item.description: Raspberry Pi 400 is your complete personal computer, built into a compact keyboard. It's our most powerful and easy-to-use computer yet.

item.title: Sex Differences in Occupational Attainment Are Here to Stay
item.description: In many nations and for many people, the sex difference in occupational attainment is a social pathology that begs for corrective intervention. The ultimate societal goal for many is equal numbers of high-achieving men and women across high-status fields, including those that typically draw more of …

item.title: The Worst Choice Ever
item.description: Donald Trump is a disaster, but Joe Biden's party is democratic in name only. Why this year's election is a vomit milkshake

item.title: I Signed Up to Study Sexual Health. What I Got Was Gender Ideology, Fetishism, and Porn
item.description: I am not a conspiracy theorist. And as recently as a year and a half ago, if someone had told me the things I am reporting here, I would have accused them of culture-war paranoia. That was before I enrolled in a professional training program that I'd hoped would expand my skills as a therapist, but …

item.title: Jack Turban's Dangerous Campaign to Smear Ethical Psychotherapy as Anti-Trans 'Conversion Therapy'
item.description: This essay is adapted from a letter published on October 21 by the listed authors in the Archives of Sexual Behavior. It has been abridged for a non-academic readership. A subset of the scholarly citations included in the original letter appear below in the form of web links. Readers who wish to rea…

item.title: Is It Better to Plant Trees or Let Forests Regrow Naturally?
item.description: Nations are pledging to plant billions of trees. But a new study shows that we've underestimated the power of natural forest regrowth to fight climate change.

item.title: FBI, Homeland Security Detail How Iranian Hackers Stole US Voter Data
item.description: The FBI and Homeland Security's CISA have detailed how Iranian hackers stole US voter info, including by exploiting badly configured websites.

item.title: The Tech Antitrust Problem No One Is Talking About
item.description: Americans pay more for broadband, have fewer choices than consumers in other countries.

item.title: Democracy Dies When Facebook and Twitter Define the Truth
item.description: Citizens should have the freedom to decide what to believe.

item.title: The Bigger the Lie... (The Wire)
item.description: The Bunk extracts a confession from a suspect using manipulation and a mock polygraph test. His reasoning gives the episode its epigraph 'the bigger the lie,...

item.title: A New Way to Plug a Human Brain Into a Computer: Via Veins
item.description: Electrodes threaded through blood vessels let people control gadgets with their minds.

item.title: US and UK Citizens Are World's Biggest Sources of Plastic Waste – Study
item.description: US population may also be third-largest producer of marine plastic pollution

item.title: How Humanity Spent Its First 20 Years in Orbit Aboard the ISS
item.description: Two decades ago, three explorers arrived at the International Space Station and marked the beginning of a permanent human presence beyond Earth.

item.title: The Robot Ships Are Coming ... Eventually
item.description: As the pandemic fuels demand for less contact and fewer sailors, shipping companies turn to AI-assisted navigation.

item.description: Journalist Glenn Greenwald shocked his global readership on Thursday, when he abruptly announced his resignation from the Intercept, the six-year-old site that became famous after publishing documents

item.title: Glenn Greenwald on His Resignation From the Intercept
item.description: The Pulitzer winner founded the Intercept to challenge official narratives and protect editorial freedom. When editors abandoned those principles, spiking a controversial story, he was forced to quit

item.title: These Drones Will Plant 40,000 Trees in a Month. By 2028, They'll Have Planted 1 Billion
item.description: We need to massively reforest the planet, in a very short period of time. Flash Forest's drones can plant trees a lot faster than humans.

item.description: Startups, universities, and major companies are vying to commercialize a nuclear fusion reactor.

item.title: Spy Agency Ducks Questions About 'Back Doors' in Tech Products
item.description: The U.S. National Security Agency is rebuffing efforts by a leading Congressional critic to determine whether it is continuing to place so-called back doors into commercial technology products, in a controversial practice that critics say damages both U.S. industry and national...

item.title: Black Separatist Militia: 'If You Attack Us, We Will Kill You'
item.description: The paramilitary group of at least a few thousand armed black members describes itself as 'America's black militia.'

item.description: The EIA expects 6,900 megawatts of battery capacity in the next few years.

item.description: Violent protests and widespread looting continued for a second night in Philadelphia on Tuesday in response to the fatal police shooting of a knife-wielding black man. The raucous night comes even …

item.title: There May Be Far More Water on the Moon Than NASA Thought
item.description: A new pair of studies reveals that the resource isn't limited to large shadowy craters. That's good news for the upcoming crewed missions.

item.title: New Nuclear Engine Concept Could Help Realize 3-Month Trips to Mars
item.description: Seattle-based Ultra Safe Nuclear Technologies (USNC-Tech) has developed a concept for a new Nuclear Thermal Propulsion (NTP) engine and delivered it to NASA. item.title: Vaccine Hopes Rise as Oxford Jab Prompts Immune Response Among Old as Well as Young Adults
item.description: One of the world's leading COVID-19 experimental vaccines produces an immune response in both young and old adults, raising hopes of a path out of the gloom and economic destruction wrought by the novel coronavirus.

item.description: Berserk Bear has had plenty of opportunity to cause serious trouble. So why hasn't it yet?

item.title: Physicists 3D Print a Boat That Could Sail Down a Human Hair
item.description: Researchers at Leiden University have 3D printed the smallest boat in the world: a 30-micrometer copy of Benchy the tug boat, a well-known 3D printer test object. This boat is so small, it could float down the interior of a human hair.

item.title: Scientists Discover the First Room-Temperature Superconductor
item.description: Physicists finally achieved the long-sought goal, but there's a catch: Their compound requires crushing pressures to keep from falling apart.

item.title: Reflections on Solzhenitsyn's Harvard Address

item.title: What Divides Us Is Class, Not Race
item.description: Black lives matter. It's become a rallying cry for those seeking social and racial justice. These three words express the idea, symbolized by the death of George Floyd, that race defines the fault …

item.description: The philosophical origins of the Woke ideology are analysed in two new books

item.title: Russians Who Pose Election Threat Have Hacked Nuclear Plants and Power Grid
item.description: The hacking group, Energetic Bear, is among Russia's stealthiest. It appears to be casting a wide net to find useful targets ahead of the election, experts said.

item.title: Aliens From These Worlds Could Be Watching Us Right Now
item.description: Astronomers have catalogued more than 3,000 exoplanets using a fairly basic detection technique known as the transit method. What if aliens are using the same technique to spy on us?

item.title: Print These Electronic Circuits Directly Onto Skin
item.description: Room-temperature sintering enables skin sensors for vital signs.

item.title: Scientists Found a New Way to Break Down the Most Common Plastic
item.description: The plastics industry produces over 88 million tons of polyethylene, the most common plastic in the world. Scientists have found a new way to upcycle it, according to a study published in Science. It could help deal with the growing plastic pollution crisis.

item.title: Former Google CEO Calls Social Networks 'Amplifiers for Idiots'
item.description: Former Google Chief Executive Officer Eric Schmidt said the 'excesses' of social media are likely to result in greater regulation of internet platforms in the coming years.

item.title: DOJ Lets Opioid Ghouls at Purdue Pharma Off With a Slap on the Wrist
item.description: The 'Empire of Pain' and the family that profited from it scored a sick joke of a settlement with the Department of Justice on Wednesday, evading accountability for their role in the nationwide opioid epidemic.

item.description: 'Iran and Russia have taken specific actions to influence public opinion relating to our election.'

item.title: Google Paid Apple Billions to Dominate Search on iPhones, Justice Department Says
item.description: An agreement worth up to $12 billion made Google the de facto choice for online search on millions of iPhones. Justice officials say the deal may be anticompetitive under U.S. law.

item.title: DOJ Antitrust Lawsuit Aims at the Heart of Google's $1 Trillion Business
item.description: After a 16-month investigation, the Department of Justice and 11 states filed an antitrust lawsuit against Google on Tuesday, arguing that the company's search app hurts search competition and disproportionately funnels traffic to Google's ad business.

item.title: Got Any Signal Up Here? Nokia to Build Mobile Network on the Moon
item.description: Struggling to get a phone signal at home on planet Earth? Perhaps you'll have better luck on the moon.

item.title: Babies May Be Drinking Millions of Microplastic Particles a Day
item.description: Scientists discover that baby bottles shed up to 16 million bits of plastic per liter of fluid. What that means for infants' health, no one can yet say.

item.title: US Indicts Sandworm, Russia's Most Destructive Cyberwar Unit
item.description: The Department of Justice has named and charged six men for allegedly carrying out many of the most costly cyberattacks in history.

item.title: Japan Going Ahead With Plan to Dump Radioactive Water Into the Sea
item.description: It appears Japan is ready to proceed with dumping over 1 million tons of contaminated water from the destroyed Fukushima nuclear plant into the ocean.

item.title: COVID-19 Cases Top 8 Million in the US
item.description: More than one out of every 50 people in the US is known to have or have had COVID-19.

item.title: Methane Emissions Are Up Even Though Natural Gas Demand Is Down
item.description: New satellite images show that the world's number of large methane hotspots increased by nearly a third in the first eight months 2020, despite industry pledges to reduce greenhouse gas pollution and tanking fuel demand tied to the pandemic.

item.description: Physicists have reached a long-sought goal. The catch is that their room-temperature superconductor requires crushing pressures to keep from falling apart.

item.title: Fracking Is Elevating Levels of Radioactivity Downwind
item.description: Hydraulic fracturing has been a big topic of the upcoming presidential election. Biden has refused to ban it, Trump has said he'll expand it hugely. But a new Harvard study suggests that the drilling practice is even more dangerous than we previously thought.

item.title: The Destruction of the Great Barrier Reef Is Clearer Than Ever
item.description: Coral populations on the Great Barrier Reef have declined precipitously in the past 20 years.

item.description: The structure of black phosphorus naturally makes channels to let lithium in.

item.description: Airliners carry a variety of computer systems that could become vulnerable to hackers and U.S. regulators haven't imposed adequate counter measures, a government watchdog report concluded.

item.description: Less than 10 per cent of the plastics we've used have been recycled. A new documentary reveals why

item.title: The Unprecedented and Illegal Campaign to Eliminate Julian Assange
item.description: Assange would never receive a fair trial in the U.S., but he's not receiving one in Britain either.

item.title: The IRS Is Being Investigated for Using Location Data Without a Warrant
item.description: The IRS used smartphone location data from a contractor to try to track Americans without a warrant.

item.description: Internal projections from one of world’s largest oil producers show an increase in its enormous contribution to global warming.

item.title: Why Humanity Destroyed Itself
item.description: The real reason we may destroy ourselves isn't really to do with politics or economics or even warfare. It has to do with our minds.

item.description: Four million figure double the previous record for most land burned as officials warn that season is 'far from over and fire potential remains high'

item.description: Researchers determined that Greenland is on track to lose more ice this century than during any of the previous 120 centuries. Christopher Intagliata reports.

item.description: A massive contact tracing effort is under way to determine when Trump and aides were contagious, raising startling questions about the debate.

item.description: 42,000-foot plumes of ash. 143-mph firenadoes. 1,500-degree heat. These wildfires are a new kind of hell on earth, and scientists are racing to learn its rules.
